tossups.question: In 2000, Piotr Drachal designed a monument to an early action of this policy featuring a wreath of flowers. A planning paper for this policy was leaked by an opposing diplomat to Quick magazine. Markus Wolf’s exposure of Gunter Guillaume as a spy led to the (*) resignation this policy’s main proponent. This policy called for recognition of the Oder-Neisse-line, aiding the Quadripartite Agreement and the Basic Treaty, and called for the replacement of the Hallstein Doctrine. For 10 points, name this cooperative policy associated with Willy Brandt.
tossups.answer: Neue Ostpolitik [ prompt on eastern policy or descriptions like “being nicer to East Germany”] <LC>
tossups.answer_formatted: Neue Ostpolitik <LC> [prompt on eastern policy or descriptions like “being nicer to East Germany]
promptable: descriptions like “being nicer to East Germany

tossups.question: One member of this family tries to help a young girl who speaks no English get home and feeds her bread, but is attacked by her Italian family. A female member of this family had the maiden name Bascomb, while another member of this family likes to watch golf, to see if they will call for (*) a caddy. A girl from this family loses her virginity to Dalton Ames and names her firstborn after her brother Quentin, who later kills himself by jumping into the Charles River. For 10 points, name this Mississippi family of fading aristocrats from Faulkner’s The Sound and the Fury.

Steve McCabe ran one by-election campaign in this county in which campaigners shadowed the Tory candidate wearing tailcoats and top hats. After her mother’s death in office, Tamsin Dunwoody failed to hold one seat in this county in a 2008 by-election, the first such Tory gain in 36 years. In two seats in this county in 2010, the MPs Nicholas and Anne (*) Winterton stood down after the expenses scandal. In 2017, Esther McVey won a seat in this county, after George Osborne didn’t recontest Tatton. For ten points, name this county with constituencies like Congleton, Macclesfield and City of Chester.

NOTE TO PLAYERS: TWO ANSWERS REQUIRED One of these people suggested that the other would lie about driving the car that JFK was in when he was shot. After meeting a woman with dwarfism at a carnival, a character based on one of these people is rebuffed by Joel; that character, Idabel Thompkins, features in the other’s debut novel, (*) Other Voices, Other Rooms. Catherine Keener and Sandra Bullock have starred as one of these people, while Toby Jones and Philip Seymour Hoffman have portrayed the other in films like Infamous. For 10 points, name these two writers who worked together on In Cold Blood and were represented as Scout and Dill in To Kill a Mockingbird.
tossups.answer: Harper Lee and Truman Capote [accept Tru and Nelle] <LC>

tossups.question: Lucullus’ grandfather attacked this region’s Vaccaei tribe without Senate approval. After Gaius Hostilius Mancinus failed to win a war in this region on the field, Tiberius Gracchus concluded that war in this site of the Sertorian War controversially peaceably. Galba launched his takeover from this region and (*) site of the Numantine War. This region was secured by a battle won with “reverse Cannae” tactics, Ilipa. Scipio Africanus won this region before attacking Africa in the Second Punic War. For 10 points, name this original home of Trajan and Hadrian, divided into Baetica, Tarraconensis, and Lusitania.
tossups.answer: Hispania [prompt on Spain or Portugal; anti-prompt on Baetica, Tarraconensis, or Lusitania until mentioned] <CB/OSC>
tossups.answer_formatted: Hispania <CB/OSC> [prompt on Spain or Portugal; anti-prompt on Baetica, Tarraconensis, or Lusitania until mentioned]

tossups.question: Stefan Jonsson argued that this painting depicts “society degree zero” and links an element in it to the flag flying from the mast of Bosch’s Ship of Fools. A sign in this painting reads “Doctrinaire Fanfares Always Succeed,” and its foreground centers on a mitre-wearing man with a massive red beard (*) holding a baton. A massive red banner reading “Vive La Sociale” looms over the title figure of this painting riding a donkey unnoticed through a giant grotesque parade. For 10 points, name this depiction of a capital city by James Ensor.
tossups.answer: Christ’s Entry Into Brussels in 1889 [or L’Entrée du Christ à Bruxelles; accept any translations that gets across the idea of Jesus Christ doing something that gets him into the city of Brussels] <JG>
tossups.answer_formatted: Christ’s Entry Into Brussels in 1889 <JG> [or L’Entrée du Christ à Bruxelles; accept any translations that gets across the idea of Jesus Christ doing something that gets him into the city of Brussels]
acceptable: any translations that gets across the idea of Jesus Christ doing something that gets him into the city of Brussels

tossups.question: One character created by this writer fails to keep a job for all of National Cheese Week, and blames "the dullest house in England" when caught lying about a staircase. In another play by this author, a character talks of "a Spanish cat of the Enlightenment" that "appreciated (*) counterpoint", and tricks his rival into angering the Freemasons by writing an opera. Another play by this author of Lettice and Lovage focuses on Dr Martin Dysart’s attempt to analyse Alan Strang, who stripped naked and blinded six horses with a spike. For 10 points, name this British playwright of Amadeus and Equus.

A teenager sings “We Are the Champions” at one of these objects, and a Julia Sawalha character slides through a tunnel while holding one in two chicken-related films. Mike Wazowski concocts a plan to release a child into the wild using ‘mainly’ these objects, and in a 2017 film Missy rotates one to send Chris to (*) the “sunken place”. It is customary to throw these objects at the screen when they appear in The Room, and Neo is awestruck when a boy uses his mind to bend a non-existent one of these things in The Matrix. Used by Woody as a mirror in Toy Story, for 10 points, name this common dining utensil.

In one of this director’s films, Johnny falls asleep while pole dancing twins perform in his room at the Chateau Marmont. Another film by this director opens as a group of boys wonder how their maths teacher produced such beautiful blonde daughters. In 2017, this director was criticised over a (*) remake which cut all black characters; in that film, a wounded Union soldier has sex with a schoolteacher played by Kirsten Dunst. In another film by this director, a Suntory whiskey advert leads Bob to connect with photographer Charlotte at a Tokyo hotel. For 10 points, name this director of The Virgin Suicides and Lost in Translation.

Injury to this joint can be assessed by the Hawkins–Kennedy manoeuvre. A SLAP tear involves damage to a structure in this joint that is lax inferiorly, permitting extended abduction. Adhesive capsulitis affects this joint in a condition named for its (*) “frozen” nature. Supraspinatus, infraspinatus and teres minor attach to the greater tubercle in this joint, which with subscapularis and their tendons, make up the rotator cuff, often injured by baseball pitchers. For 10 points, name this ball-and-socket joint in which the scapula articulates with the humerus.

Two concentric cylinders are rotated relative to each other in the Couette configuration often used to measure this quantity. The time evolution of the vorticity is given by one form of this quantity times the laplacian of the vorticity. Expressing the (*) shear tensor in the Cauchy equations in terms of this quantity and velocity gives the Navier Stokes equations. The ratio of inertial forces to forces due to this quantity is the Reynolds number. Newtonian fluids have constant values for, for 10 points, what resistance of a fluid to flow?.

One composer from this country called for the lower strings to be tuned down a semitone in his B minor cello sonata. A work for tenor, chorus, and orchestra by that composer used the words of Psalm 55 as a metaphor for the sufferings of this country. Two bassoons playing a minor 6th apart introduce the (*) “Game of Pairs” in a concerto for orchestra by a composer from this country. Another composer developed micropolyphony in pieces such as Atmospheres after fleeing the Soviet invasion of this country. For 10 points, identify this home country of György [JURJ] Ligeti, Zoltán Kodály, and Béla Bartók.

Joseph Lyons intervened in a diplomatic crisis sparked by this activity involving a leaked conversation between Bill Woodfull and Pelham Warner. The Philadelphian Bart King achieved fame in this activity. A protest “mourning the death of democracy” during this activity led to the exile of Henry (*) Olonga. Jamaican PM Michael Manley wrote a history of this activity in the West Indies, which is also the subject of a 1963 C.L.R. James work. For 10 points, name this sport, associated with contentious “bodyline” tactics in a 1930s Ashes tour.
tossups.answer: Cricket [accept early buzz of bodyline; accept bowling bouncers; accept short-pitched bowling] <HO>
tossups.answer_formatted: Cricket <HO> [accept early buzz of bodyline; accept bowling bouncers; accept short-pitched bowling]

tossups.question: In a short story named for one of these events, a zoologist blames an aristocrat for spreading bad habits like card playing around town. After one of these events in War and Peace, a man leaves his unfaithful lover to join the freemasons. In one novel, one of these events takes place after Zaretsky (*) does not apologise, while in A Hero of Our Time, an attempted sabotage at one of these events fails and a body falls off the edge of a cliff. For 10 points, name these events, one of which takes place between Eugene Onegin and Vladimir Lensky, and which may involve pistols at dawn.

DESCRIPTION ACCEPTABLE This process forms the bottom-most part of a diagram nicknamed “Coleman’s Boat.” Anthony Giddens’ structuration theory holds that structure is both medium and outcome of this process, and Bruno Latour created a framework whose basic analytical unit is a compound of a network and those doing this. (*) Pierre Bourdieu wrote an Outline of a Theory of [this process], and Talcott Parsons formulated the AGIL paradigm of this in a work titled The Structure of [this process]. For 10 points, “agency” is the ability to do this, the relation of which with structure is a key issue of sociology.
tossups.answer: social action [accept word forms; also accept practice given the actual words used; also accept agency until mentioned; prompt on general answers like just doing things with “a more technical term for which is?”] <JG>
tossups.answer_formatted: social action <JG> [accept word forms; also accept practice given the actual words used; also accept agency until mentioned; prompt on general answers like just doing things with “a more technical term for which is?]
promptable: general answers like just doing things with “a more technical term for which is?

tossups.question: Macros in this software can take at most nine parameters, and its six modes include restricted horizontal. This software measures badness with the glue set ratio, that quantifies how much boxes are stretched or shrunk. Its `phantom' command is used to produce invisible output. This software’s class (*) Beamer creates slide presentations, and its version numbers converge to pi. Leslie Lamport added macros to this program to provide default styles for chapters and sections. Donald Knuth designed, for 10 points, what typesetting software for mathematics?
tossups.answer: TeX [(or LaTeX; pronunciation /tɛx/ but accept /tɛk/ or /tɛks/; accept specific answers such as MiKTeX or AMS-LaTeX which contain Tex] <RF>
tossups.answer_formatted: TeX <RF> [(or LaTeX; pronunciation /tɛx/ but accept /tɛk/ or /tɛks/; accept specific answers such as MiKTeX or AMS-LaTeX which contain Tex]

tossups.question: The energy associated with bending these structures is quantified in the Helfrich model. These structures display a small peak in their heat capacity at their pre-transition temperature where they change form their “ripple” phase. These structures can wrap round on themselves to form (*) lamellae and they exist in equilibrium with micelles. The incorporation of cholesterol can increase the rigidity and decrease the permeability of these structures. For 10 points, name these flat sheets formed by two layers of amphiphilic lipid molecules.
tossups.answer: Lipid Membranes (or bilayers, accept vesicles or liposomes) <EM>
tossups.metadata: or bilayers, accept vesicles or liposomes

tossups.question: Reflections Upon Laughter and Remarks Upon [this work] collects several of Francis Hutcheson’s attacks on this work. F.B. Kaye revived interest in this work, which examines changing facial hair fashions to prove that worth is subjective. This work’s second version added a critique of charity schools and (*) it calls envy and vanity “ministers of industry.” The prosperity of this work’s title figures collapses when they become honest and thrifty. For 10 points, name this work, subtitled “Private Vices, Public Benefits,” by Bernard Mandeville.
tossups.answer: The Fable of the Bees: or, Private Vices, Public Benefits. <HO>
tossups.answer_formatted: The Fable of the Bees: or, Private Vices, Public Benefits. <HO>
acceptable: The Fable of the Bees: or, Private Vices, Public Benefits. <HO>
Fable of the Bees: or, Private Vices, Public Benefits. <HO>

tossups.question: In Hebron, a version of this festival “of the Window” celebrates a miraculous bag of gold that thwarted a greedy pasha. This festival’s story is recorded in one of two Biblical books not to mention God. UChicago began an annual debate between a Passover foodstuff and one from (*) this festival. Gift baskets called mishloach manot are exchanged in this festival, and at it one should drink until one can “no longer distinguish between cursed Haman and blessed Mordechai.” For 10 points, name this Jewish festival which celebrates Esther preventing a massacre of Persian Jews.

Vishnu’s only female avatar, Mohini, tricked the demon Bhasmasur into killing himself in this manner. In Varnavat, the Pandavas barely escape Purochana’s plot to kill them in this manner in the House of Lacquer. Zao Jun became the Kitchen God after dying in this manner, and Sun (*) Wukong gained his ability to see through demons’ disguises after an attempt to kill him in this manner. Kamadeva was destroyed in this manner by Shiva’s third eye. For 10 points, a poisoned shirt prompted Heracles to try to kill himself in which manner?
tossups.answer: Being incinerated [accept any answer that remotely involves dying in/by means of fire, by means of a hearth or oven, or by being turned to ashes; prompt on dancing until “Pandavas” and do not accept or prompt after] <JG>
tossups.answer_formatted: Being incinerated <JG> [accept any answer that remotely involves dying in/by means of fire, by means of a hearth or oven, or by being turned to ashes; prompt on dancing until “Pandavas or do not accept or prompt after]
acceptable: any answer that remotely involves dying in/by means of fire, by means of a hearth

tossups.question: This island is the site of the Grasberg Mine, the world’s largest gold and second-largest copper mine, which sits within 4 km of this island’s highest point, Nemangkawi. The north-western and south-eastern points of this island are formed by the(*) Bird’s Head and Bird’s Tail Peninsulas, respectively. The shape of this island is often compared to a bird of paradise, one of which appears on the flag of one country on this island. For 10 points, name this second-largest island of the world, split between Indonesia and a namesake country.

The British professional body for this subject awarded Neil Armstrong a Special Gold Medal in 1970; previous recipients include Vivian Fuchs. The headquarters of that same body was where David Livingstone lay in state before burial in Westminster Abbey. The term “manpower” was coined by a man who formulated (*) “heartland theory” and introduced the academic study of this subject at Oxford University, Halford Mackinder. For 10 points, name this subject that deals with the spatial distribution, change and origins of things in the world.

A character with this profession employs a character “as beautiful and wicked as Satan”, Miguel Angel Face. After a lampoon of him is found on a cathedral door, a man with this profession dictates his thoughts to his secretary Policarpo Patino in a novel by Augusto Roa Bastos. The last day in the life (*) of a man with this profession is featured in the Mario Vargas Llosa novel The Feast of the Goat, which traces the impact of that man’s 1961 assassination in the Dominican Republic. For 10 points, name this profession whose real-world counterparts included Rafael Trujillo and Augusto Pinochet.
tossups.answer: dictator [accept Supreme Leader or El Supremo; accept President; prompt on just leaders or politicians] <JK>
tossups.answer_formatted: dictator <JK> [accept Supreme Leader or El Supremo; accept President; prompt on just leaders or politicians]

tossups.question: In one speech, this man said that “a plough team coming over the brow of a hill” was “the one eternal sight of England.” After this leader’s retirement, Lord Beaverbrook stoked controversy over this man’s iron gates. This man popularised the theory that (*) “the bomber will always get through.” This man and Neville Chamberlain were the main targets of Michael Foot’s Guilty Men. This man won a landslide by capitalising on the Zinoviev Letter and the collapse of the Liberal vote. For 10 points, name this three-time Tory Prime Minister, who alternated terms with Ramsay MacDonald.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about a certain object’s use in philosophy, for 10 points each:
answers: a brain [generously prompt on heads for reasons that make sense given the next parts]

the extended mind thesis [also accept vehicle externalism or any of Rowlands’ “four E’s” of embodied, embedded, enacted, or extended cognition and word forms; prompt on situated cognition and word forms] <JG>
parts: Ned Block argued that functionalism implies that the population of China could form one of these things. Another thought experiment centers on asking if your life is a simulation run on one of these things “in a vat.”
This creator of the “Twin Earth” thought experiment was important in popularizing the “brain in a vat.” He summarized his position of semantic externalism as “meaning just ain’t in the head.”

This position associated with Mark Rowlands, Andy Clark, and David Chalmers holds that cognition itself is not purely in the head but also heavily involves an agent’s environment and its interactions with it.
answers_formatted: a brain [generously prompt on heads for reasons that make sense given the next parts]

the extended mind thesis <JG> [also accept vehicle externalism or any of Rowlands’ “four E’s” of embodied, embedded, enacted, or extended cognition and word forms; prompt on situated cognition or word forms]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about the development of modern musical notation:
answers: Guido of Arezzo [or Guido Aretinus; or Guido Aretino; or Guido Monaco; or Guy of Arezzo; or Guy d'Arezzo, prompt on Guido]
parts: These marks developed in medieval Europe as a means of preserving inflections in plainchant, and were later employed to show the shape of a melody. Examples of these marks include the punctum and the scandicus.

This 11th-century music scholar is widely credited with the innovation of modern staff notation, as his use of two black lines alongside the existing red and yellow F and C lines allowed for a definite pitch relationship to be established.
Guido's staves employed only four lines, and it was not until the 1300s that staves with this many lines, now the standard number used in musical notation, were developed.
answers_formatted: Guido of Arezzo [or Guido Aretinus; or Guido Aretino; or Guido Monaco; or Guy of Arezzo; or Guy d'Arezzo, prompt on Guido]

bonuses.leadin: Candidates for this object include ones named for the filmmaker Arne Sucksdorff and for the town of Mockfjärd while its user may be a serial killer called “the Laser Man” or the so-called “33-year-old.” For 10 points each:
answers: the gun used in the Olof Palme assassination [accept any description that include a firearm and the death of Palme]
apartheid [prompt on answers like South African racism] <JG>
parts: Describe this object, which triggered a massive hunt for .357 magnum Smith and Wesson revolvers after it was used to kill a man walking home from a screening of The Mozart Brothers with his wife, Lisbet.

Another beloved assassinated Swede was a member of this family founded by a Napoleonic general. He saved thousands from the Nazis with the White Buses but was killed by the Lehi while mediating Arab-Israeli tensions.

“Prime Evil” Eugene de Kock claims that the Palme assassination retaliated for his vocal opposition to this policy that created “bantustans.” It was ended by F.W. de Klerk and the founder of Spear of the Nation.
answers_formatted: the gun used in the Olof Palme assassination [accept any description that include a firearm or the death of Palme]
acceptable: the gun used in the Olof Palme assassination
gun used in the Olof Palme assassination
any description that include a firearm

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about music streaming services:
parts: This Swedish company founded by Daniel Ek is arguably the world’s most popular streaming service. Taylor Swift famously criticised this service for not fairly compensating artists and took her music off the site in 2014.
Another big Scandinavian streaming service is Tidal, backed by Jay-Z. One of the main attractions of Tidal’s service is this type of audio based on Huffman coding, achieved using formats like FLAC.

Soundcloud is also a popular platform, particularly with young aspiring musicians. The site has produced “Soundcloud rappers” like this artist, who used it to post his mixtapes Live Forever, Crybaby and Come Over When You’re Sober.

bonuses.leadin: One of the many really interesting things about glaciers is that their flow depends a lot on how much water there is at the base. For 10 points each, answer some questions about the effect of water on glacier flow.
parts: The key variable that determines the effect of basal water on glacier flow is this one, measured in Pascals.
Higher water pressures allow this class of fast glacier motion to occur, in addition to the slow ice creep caused by the glacier’s own internal deformation.

If water pressure reaches or exceeds the ice overburden pressure, then this phenomenon can occur, leading to the ice becoming totally decoupled from its bed and locally sliding very fast, as all its weight is borne by the water.

bonuses.leadin: Frederick Douglass managed the Haitian Pavilion at an event in this city. For 10 points each:
answers: St. Louis [also accept the 1904 World’s Fair, even though we asked for the city; Ota Benga was the pygmy kept at the Bronx Zoo because racism] <FHR>
parts: Name this American city which hosted the World’s Columbian Exposition in 1893. That event is one of two World’s Fairs memorialised on this city’s flag.
The centrepiece of the Columbian Exposition was this amusement ride, whose name has come to apply generically to its imitators. It stood 80 metres tall and took nine minutes to rotate.

The World’s Fair in this city ran along with the Summer Olympics, featured a bullfight riot, and promoted science and technology. More appalling “exhibits” included Geronimo and future Bronx Zoo resident Ota Benga.
answers_formatted: St. Louis <FHR> [also accept the 1904 World’s Fair, even though we asked for the city; Ota Benga was the pygmy kept at the Bronx Zoo because racism]

bonuses.leadin: Gustavus Adolphus was assassinated at a court ball in 1789, and while Scribe and Auder based a grand opera on the plot, it needed to be disguised in Austrian-dominated Italy. For 10 points each:
answers: Va, pensiero [accept Chorus of the Hebrew Slaves]
parts: While the politics of the composer of Un ballo in maschera are ambiguous, this slogan was associated with Risorgimento. It supported the ascension of the first king of a united Italy since the 6th century.
At Verdi’s funeral, 28,000 people lining the streets sang this chorus from Nabucco in the spirit of the movement. Inspired by Psalm 137, the first line means, “Go, thought, on wings of gold.”
The performance of “Va, pensiero” at Verdi’s funeral was led by this Italian conductor. He gained fame as the first conductor of the NBC Symphony Orchestra, and was known for his brisk style.

bonuses.leadin: This poem describes the racism faced by its author, including the comment ‘“Their colour is a diabolic dye”’. For 10 points each:
answers: “On Being Brought from Africa to America”
George III <JK> NOTE: DESCRIPTION ACCEPTABLE FOR THE FIRST PART OF THIS BONUS
parts: Name this poem, which opens “Twas mercy brought me from my Pagan land”, and describes the author’s title journey.

That poem is a work by this poet, the first female African-American whose works were published. Her works including “To His Excellency George Washington” were published in Poems on Various Subjects, Religious and Moral.

In 1768, Wheatley wrote To The King’s Most Excellent Majesty, written in honour of this British king’s repeal of the Stamp Acts. American opinions on this king rather changed during the Revolutionary War.
answers_formatted: “On Being Brought from Africa to America”
George III <JK> NOTE: DESCRIPTION ACCEPTABLE FOR THE FIRST PART OF THIS BONUS
acceptable: “On Being Brought from Africa to America”
“On Being Brought from Africa to America”
George III <JK> NOTE: DESCRIPTION ACCEPTABLE FOR THE FIRST PART OF THIS BONUS
George III <JK> NOTE: DESCRIPTION ACCEPTABLE FOR THE FIRST PART OF THIS BONUS

bonuses.leadin: One instance of this sort of action involved cross-dressing specifically to seduce Julius Caesar’s second wife Pompeia, whom Caesar divorced simply because she “ought not even to be under suspicion.” For 10 points each:
answers: profaning the mysteries [accept any description that gets across the idea of violating the holiness and/or secrecy of a mystery or all-woman cult or religious order/ceremony; anti-prompt on answers that specify the Eleusinian Mysteries or the Cult of Bona Dea]
Syracuse [or Syracusa; yes, calling the Sicilian Expedition an “attack on Syracuse” is a massive oversimplification]
Marcus Tullius Cicero [also accept “Mark Tully the Chickpea”] <CB/JG>
parts: This sort of action was, aside from alleged incest, P. Clodius Pulcher’s most infamous crime. Another type of this action involved declaring prorrhesis, calling oneself a hierophant, and/or using kykeon in a private home.

Alcibiades was accused of not only profaning the Eleusinian Mysteries, but also mutilating statues of Hermes on the eve of an attack on this city. A man from this city allegedly told a Roman soldier not to disturb his circles.

This legendary Roman orator often alluded to Pulcher’s indiscretions in speeches like Pro Milone. This author of On the Commonwealth and On Duties exposed Catiline’s Conspiracy and was killed at Mark Antony’s behest.
answers_formatted: profaning the mysteries [accept any description that gets across the idea of violating the holiness and/or secrecy of a mystery or all-woman cult or religious order/ceremony; anti-prompt on answers that specify the Eleusinian Mysteries or the Cult of Bona Dea]
Syracuse [or Syracusa; yes, calling the Sicilian Expedition an “attack on Syracuse” is a massive oversimplification]
Marcus Tullius Cicero <CB/JG> [also accept “Mark Tully the Chickpea”]
acceptable: any description that gets across the idea of violating the holiness and/or secrecy of a mystery

bonuses.leadin: These organism’s salivary glands contain giant polytene chromosomes. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these model organisms studied by Thomas Hunt Morgan.
Fruit flies possess the “compound” variety of these organs. In humans, they contain the vitreous humour and a dark layer called the choroid.
These structures are the units of Drosophila’s compound eyes. Studies of these structures led to the elucidation of the activation of the oncoprotein Ras.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about incest and patricide in Greek mythology, for 10 points each:
parts: Name this Theban king who ordered his son to be exposed following a prophecy of patricide and incest. Needless to say that son killed him while this king traveled by chariot to Delphi.
This son of Laius discovers his true birth and blinds himself in a fit of grief over his unnatural acts of murder and incest after the suicide of his wife and mother, Jocasta.
In an epic sequel to the Odyssey titled for him, this son of Odysseus by Circe travels to Ithaca where he accidentally kills his father and marries Penelope. Telemachus then proceeds to marry Circe.

bonuses.leadin: “All women become like their mothers. That’s their tragedy. No man does. That’s his.” For 10 points each, answer some questions on Oscar Wilde’s women:
parts: While Gwendolyn may be doomed to become like Lady Bracknell in The Importance of Being Earnest, this Roman-inspired first name of Miss Prism might suggest she is set for happier days.

In another Wilde play, Lady Windermere is seen preparing for her coming-of-age birthday ball. When Lord Darlington pays her a visit, she shows him this lovely title object of the play, which her husband has bought her.
Wilde wrote Salome with this actress in mind for the lead, although it was banned by British censors before it could be performed. She was also the first woman to play Hamlet on film.

bonuses.leadin: This process may be either “declarative” or “procedural”, depending on whether the information involved is explicit or implicit. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this human ability. The limits of the “short-term” variety of this ability were explored in George A. Miller’s 1956 paper “The Magical Number 7, Plus or Minus 2”, which discusses “chunking”.

This German psychologist did early research on memory, testing himself using nonsense syllables. Perhaps more usefully for quizzers, he also formulated a “forgetting curve” to show the speed at which we forget new facts.

Nowadays we know a lot more about how memory functions in the brain thanks partly to patients such as this man, who developed severe amnesia in 1953 after William Scoville removed his hippocampi to treat his epilepsy.

bonuses.leadin: Veronica Forrest-Thomson's Poetic Artifice was published forty years ago this year. For 10 points each:
parts: Forrest-Thomson's critical work was heavily indebted to this man. She paid tribute to him in her second volume of poetry, Language-Games, which is titled for a concept in this thinker's Philosophical Investigations.

In “Cordelia: or, ‘A Poem Should Not Mean, But Be’”, Forrest-Thomson claims that this man thinks the Cambridge University Library has got his middle name wrong, because the "H" actually stands for "Hah". This author of Kitchen Poems part-supervised Forrest-Thomson's PhD.

In Poetic Artifice, Forrest-Thomson criticises writers who think they have access to “reality in its unmediated state”. According to her, this author of “Born Yesterday” is “almost embarrassingly lucid” in his poem “Mr Bleaney”.

bonuses.leadin: One consequence of these statements is that the Seebeck and Peltier coefficients are equal. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these statements often regarded as a “fourth law of thermodynamics”, which state that the cross-coefficients for kinetic coefficients in irreversible processes are equal.

Onsager’s reciprocal relations rely on the fact that microscopic dynamics are reversible. However, this law states that entropy always increases with time. The apparent disagreement is the root of Loschmidt’s paradox.

Loschmidt’s paradox can be resolved through this theorem which states that when there is a process where energy is dispersed into heat, there exists a reverse process which relies on thermal fluctuations.

bonuses.leadin: This ruler agreed to provide both material support and troops to Dutch rebels against Spanish rule in the 1585 Treaty of Nonsuch. For 10 points each:
answers: Elizabeth I [prompt on partial answer; also accept nicknames like the Virgin Queen or Gloriana]
Antwerp [which also got hit with a “French Fury” in 1583]
parts: Name this ruler, who thus provoked the ire of Philip II, who commissioned an attack on this ruler that became the subject of this ruler’s Tilbury Speech, in which she proclaimed her “heart and stomach of a king.”

The Nonsuch Treaty was prompted by a 1576 siege of this repeatedly besieged Belgian city that ended in a sack by mutinous tercios in the best-known “Spanish Fury”. Today this city is known for its diamond markets.

This ridiculously unfortunate town was subjected not only to its own 1572 “Spanish Fury” by the Duke of Alba, but also to an “English Fury” by Dutch Calvinists and Nonsuch-supplied troops under John Norreys in 1580.
answers_formatted: Elizabeth I [prompt on partial answer; also accept nicknames like the Virgin Queen or Gloriana]
Antwerp [which also got hit with a “French Fury” in 1583]

bonuses.leadin: These elements react vigorously with water to release hydrogen gas. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these elements found on the far left of the periodic table such as lithium and sodium.
Group I metals tend to have a high affinity for these compounds often used as phase-transfer catalysts. They can be formed by the cyclisation of oligoethylene glycols.
Group I metals can react with less electropositive metals or metalloids to form these intermetallic ionic compounds which contain polyatomic polyanions.

bonuses.leadin: Haute cuisine time! For 10 points each, answer some questions on French regions famous for their food products:
parts: This region of south-eastern France, whose historical capital is Grenoble, is particularly associated with a style of potato dish that involves a shedload of cream and thinly-sliced potatoes.
To the north-east of the Dauphiné lies this other historical region based around Chambéry, which is famous for the tartiflette, a dish of potatoes, reblochon cheese, lardons and onions.

Further north and west of Savoy in eastern France is this historical region, whose major towns include Dijon and Auxerre [oc-sare], and which gives the French version of its name to a type of beef casserole cooked with red wine.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions on the influence of rivers on American painting, for 10 points each:
answers: Fur Traders Descending the Missouri [also accept its original title French Trader & Half-Breed Son] <JK>
parts: This American artistic movement was named after New York’s main river. Paintings from this movement include The Oxbow by Thomas Cole and Niagara Falls by Frederic Edwin Church.

This painter depicted his mate on the Schuylkill river after winning a rowing competition in Max Schmitt in a Single Scull. Another of his works shows a professor conducting a practical lecture at Jefferson Medical College.

Debate continues over whether the leftmost figure in this 1845 genre painting is a bear cub or a cat. In this painting by George Caleb Bingham, the two title figures sit lazily in a canoe, rowing down the title river.
answers_formatted: Fur Traders Descending the Missouri <JK> [also accept its original title French Trader & Half-Breed Son]

bonuses.leadin: This author described wandering around a dank forest with his lover in the poem Rain in the Pinewood, part of his collection Halcyon. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Italian Decadent author, whose novels include The Triumph of Death. That novel’s references to the Nietzschean superman foreshadow this author’s later support of the Fascists.

One play by d’Annunzio is titled for this classic literary character, who, both in the play and the work on which it is based, is killed by her husband Giovanni after sleeping with his brother Paolo Malatesta.
This poet, whom Giacomo Leopardi referred to as the “glorious father of Tuscan verse”, first introduced the character of Francesca da Rimini in his poem Inferno.

bonuses.leadin: The first of these figures, Rishabhanatha, is said to have lived for nearly 600 quintillion years. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these venerated figures, the most recent of which was Mahavira. Their name literally means ‘ford-makers’, and the followers of the religion Mahavira historically founded in reaching enlightenment.

Tirthankaras are central figures in this nonviolent Indian religion, originally one of the Sramana movements along with Buddhism. It is divided into the nudist Digambara sect and the white-clad Svetambara sect.

Jains believe that the current cosmic half-cycle has this many tirthankaras. Champat Rai Jain argued that the tirthankaras are the same as the “elders” mentioned in Revelation 4:4, of which there are also this number.

bonuses.leadin: A central character in this film states “charging someone for murder out here is like giving out speed tickets at the Indy 500” after another character is charged for killing four double agents. For 10 points each:
answers: Spec Ops: The Line (prompt on partial answer) <Theo>
parts: Name this film which depicts Willard travelling up the Mung River during the Vietnam War

In Apocalypse Now, Willard is already accustomed to ‘the horror’ that surrounds him before he hunts for Kurtz, unlike Marlow, who appears in this novel, written by Joseph Conrad, which served as the source material for Apocalypse Now.
A video game which took inspiration from Heart of Darkness is this 2012 shooter developed by Yager. It follows Captain Martin Walker as he slowly spirals out of control in a post-catastrophe Dubai.

bonuses.leadin: Since we’ve had enough questions about maps, let’s have some questions about mops instead. For ten points each:
parts: The inventor of the modern mop is usually said to be Manuel Corominas, who introduced his ‘Rodex’ brand mops while working in this country’s city of Zaragoza. He was born in Logrono, the capital of this country’s Rioja region.

Another great leap forward in cleaning history was Levi Dickinson’s use of a Shaker broom vise to make the sturdier brooms out of this plant. This common African food crop is called “red’ in the title of a Mo Yan novel.

Many modern breakthroughs have been made by this German manufacturer of high-pressure washers. Sales of their trademark yellow equipment make them by far the global market leader in cleaning technology.

bonuses.leadin: Following promotion to the top division in 2014, this club was playing in its first international tournament when it reached the final of the Copa Sudamericana. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Brazilian football club, who never played that final, because almost the entire team and managerial staff were killed in a plane crash en route to it.
Despite not playing the final, Chapecoense won the 2016 Copa Sudamerica after this Colombian team, their intended opponents, suggested they be awarded the title and prize money.

In December 2017, Chapecoense’s squad of new signings and promoted youth team players extraordinarily finished 8th in Brazilian league, qualifying for this top international club competition in South America. This competition is named for figures such as Pedro I and Simón Bolívar.
